2.1.b.task: Can ask someone for their name

3.1.task: Can spell their name and ask for the spelling of a word to be written down

3.2.task: Can use very basic polite stock phrases in a very limited way

2.1.a.task: Can name common types of beverages

2.1.b.task: Can use some detailed language related to the taste of food

2.1.c.task: Can name some less common types of meat, fish, fruit and vegetables

2.2.a.task: Can react to and express opinions regarding practical questions of where to go and what to do

2.2.b.task: Can compare and contrast alternatives about what to do, where to go, etc.

3.1.task: Can give supporting details using that + be + when, where, what or why

3.2.task: Can construct phrases with wh-question words followed by verbs in the infinitive

2.1.task: Can use a range of vague language related to hedging meaning

3.1.task: Can talk formally about future events and situations using due/be to/set to

3.2.task: Can report speech naturally and fluently using grammatical changes when appropriate

3.3.task: Can talk about things expected to happen in the past using meant/supposed to

2.1.a.task: Can express potential consequences of a series of actions or events with native-like fluency

2.2.task: Can use advanced language related to the review of a film

3.1.a.task: Can make complex comparisons with native-like accuracy

3.1.b.task: Can use complex comparative expressions to emphasize a positive or negative concept in a conversation
